search_parameters.q: what is the new shingles vaccine

search_information.query_displayed: what is the new shingles vaccine

related_questions.question: What is the difference between the old and new shingles vaccine?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Effectiveness: Shingrix provides significantly better and longer-lasting protection against both shingles and postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) than Zostavax. Shingrix is estimated to be 97% effective, while Zostavax's effectiveness waned significantly over time.
Type of Vaccine: Shingrix is a recombinant subunit vaccine, while Zostavax was a live-attenuated vaccine.
Live Virus: Shingrix does not contain live virus, making it safer for individuals with weakened immune systems.
Number of Doses: Shingrix requires two doses, while Zostavax was a single dose.
Availability: Zostavax is no longer available in the US.
Recommendations: The CDC recommends Shingrix for healthy adults aged 50 and older, as well as for some adults aged 19 and older with weakened immune systems.
Even if you had Zostavax, you should get Shingrix .
Shingrix can be given regardless of whether you have had chickenpox or shingles .
Shingrix can be given even if you've had shingles before .
If you had Zostavax, wait at least 5 years before getting Shingrix .

related_questions.question: What is the newest shingles vaccine called?
related_questions.title: AI Overview

related_questions.question: Why has Shingrix replaced Zostavax?
related_questions.snippet: In Australia, recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV, sold as Shingrix) replaced Zostavax on the National Immunisation Program (NIP) in 2023 due to its better efficacy. A subsidised shingles vaccination is available under the NIP for: people aged 65 and over. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 50 and over.
related_questions.title: Shingles vaccine linked to dementia risk reduction - RACGP

related_questions.question: Do I really need the new shingles vaccine?
related_questions.snippet: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) says that adults age 50 and older should get the Shingrix vaccine to prevent shingles and complications from the. condition This is true for people who have had shingles and those who have not.
related_questions.title: Shingles vaccine: Should I get it? - Mayo Clinic

text_blocks.snippet: The "new" shingles vaccine is Shingrix, a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) recommended for adults 50 years and older. It is a two-dose series administered 2 to 6 months apart. Shingrix is significantly more effective than the older Zostavax vaccine, offering over 90% protection against shingles and related complications.
snippet_highlighted_words: Shingrix, a recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) recommended for adults 50 years and older

list.title: Effectiveness:
list.snippet: Shingrix is highly effective, with studies showing 97% efficacy in preventing shingles in adults aged 50-69 and 91% in those 70 and older. It's also effective for individuals with weakened immune systems.

list.title: Two-dose series:
list.snippet: The vaccine requires two doses for optimal protection, and the doses should be spaced 2 to 6 months apart.

list.title: Recommended for:
list.snippet: Shingrix is recommended for adults 50 years and older and for individuals 18 and older who are at increased risk of shingles due to immunocompromisation.

list.title: Not for chickenpox:
list.snippet: Shingrix is not used to prevent chickenpox.

list.title: Stronger immune response:
list.snippet: The vaccine works by triggering a stronger immune response, leading to long-lasting protection against shingles and its complications.

list.title: Side effects:
list.snippet: Some individuals may experience side effects, such as pain or redness at the injection site, fatigue, muscle pain, headache, shivering, fever, stomach pain, or nausea. These are generally mild and temporary.

list.title: Replaces Zostavax:
list.snippet: In many countries, including the US, Zostavax has been withdrawn and replaced by Shingrix due to its superior effectiveness.

list.title: Even if you had shingles or Zostavax:
list.snippet: You should still get Shingrix even if you have previously had shingles or received the Zostavax vaccine.
